Do not take me not recommending this DLC as me disliking it. In fact, I adore this DLC for so many reasons. The art direction, the interesting trinkets, the music, the Thing from the Stars, and the Districts added by this are not just nothing to scoff at, they're universally amazing. The art is a perfect homage to the Color out of Space, and takes it in a wonderful direction that is not only unique but utterly gorgeous, and the music is similarly great. As well, the trinkets added by this are almost universally interesting, quirky, and add something to the game that generally wasn't there before. As well, the last part I love is the new roaming boss in The Thing from the Stars, which is a fun and challenging boss (though not very fun for newer players) with cool and varied rewards.

However, this DLC has a crippling flaw in the worst place it could possibly have it: the Farmstead. The first few expeditions the Farmstead throws at the player are actually quite good as tutorials and explanations of how the main attraction of the DLC works. However, the problems start once the Endless Harvest becomes an option.

Simply put, the Endless harvest is a fun concept crippled by its balancing and randomness. Darkest Dungeon is a game heavily designed around RNG mitigation with the trinket and quirk systems, so an area where not only does the player have random modifiers (which are VERY significant to gameplay and can either doom you or set you up for an easy win on a whim), often random rewards for surviving each wave, and random enemy compositions just feels bad to me. Far too often I end up feeling like I don't have any control over how my run in the Farmstead goes and can only hold on as tight as my heroes get tossed into god knows what. I understand that's the point of the DLC's themeing, but it creates a huge problem with the actual gameplay that I don't really like.

Speaking of poor gameplay decisions, the Endless Harvest has an incredibly strict meta team composition of Vestal/Jester/two Shieldbreakers. I already disdain the Shieldbreaker for being incredibly overpowered, but the way that the Farmstead forces this incredibly boring combo on the player as the only meaningful option to get anywhere just sucks. The stress and damage that can only inconsistently be dealt with out of combat means that the Jester and Vestal are a requirement for the area, and the two Shieldbreakers are the only heroes that have the ability to get around all of the generally unfair enemies and abilities the Farmstead often throws at the player. Since options like bleed and blight are too reliant on specific situations, they are completely useless, and most other characters simply can't keep up with the stress or damage requirements the farmstead imposes. This is worsened by the enemy design introduced with this area especially, with many being either outright unfair or incredibly annoying.

Enemies like plow horses being able to stealth themselves while putting themselves in the generally safe rank 3/4 before going for a full party shuffle is just blatantly unfair, the constant use of backline enemies that are far more durable than they should be, and the ridiculous amount of stress the room transitions pile onto the player at all times means that anything outside of the meta is massively handicapped. As well, the rewards from the Farmstead aren't even all that good for acquiring large amounts of shards for the previously mentioned cool trinkets and Districts. Overall, the gameplay is too focused on some really boring strategies, is too rigid, and is not very rewarding at all.

All in all, The Color of Madness is a beautiful, complex, interesting mess. The issues I have with this DLC are simply too great for me to truly recommend it for most, but if you like the trinkets and concept and are willing to sit through a lot of grinding and some bad mechanics, there certainly is a lot of appeal here. It's good enough for literally being 5 dollars, isn't too impactful on the base game unlike a CERTAIN DLC, nor does it add anything blatantly overpowered like a CERTAIN pair of DLC, nor does it add anything too awful. If it had some serious balance and design changes for things like colors, enemies, DOT viability, and application of rewards, I would wholeheartedly endorse this DLC.

If you're looking to pick up DLCs to go along with the fantastic main game, or spice things up for your next run, I would absolutely recommend this above Crimson Court (CC). While both DLCs are great, one of the main problems I've found with CC is how intrusive it is to the main gameplay. What with all the CC enemies invading other areas, The Crimson Curse, and the roaming boss that keeps me up at night in fear. If you aren't accustomed to the main game, or prepared to switch up your playstyle to accommodate, the Crimson Court DLC will absolutely wipe the floor with you.

However, the Color of Madness DLC (CoM) is relatively non-intrusive, and it compliments the main game especially well. Again, I'd like to reiterate that I don't think that CC is a necessarily bad DLC, but the way CoM flows into the main game simply fits. The additions it adds only compliment the main gameplay, instead of changing it altogether. To give an example, a few new quirks have been added in this DLC. A lot of these quirks fall in line with a majority of the quirks in the game, such as the CoM-introduced quirks Hot to Trot, Natural, or Daredevil. These quirks act about how you'd expect them to, but along with these quirks are the Prismatic quirks. These quirks are automatically reinforced on the heroes they appear on, and cannot be swapped out by other quirks outside of removing them via the Sanitarium. Additionally, these quirks can only occur on one person per roster. These new quirks switch up the ways you would handle typical quirk management, proposing new questions and problems for attaining these quirks on your heroes. These quirks are powerful, but the problems lie in finding where they would work best in your party, as there can only be one person with that quirk in your entire roster. However, you're never [i]forced[/i] to handle these quirks and minmax them to the highest degree, and they don't require a total playstyle shift as something like the Crimson Curse would. It's a neat addition to the game that compliments the base Darkest Dungeon experience by building on what you've learned, instead of adding a completely new mechanic altogether.

I feel as though a lot of the additions introduced in the CoM DLC follow this philosophy of building upon mechanics instead of introducing entirely new ones. The new ideas it brings up add a new flavor of play to the game, although it's not as wildly unique as the additions in CC. While I adore the two DLCs to death, CoM will always rest as my favorite due to how it went about introducing its ideas and additions. It's a fantastic DLC that spices up the Darkest Dungeon experience without out and out changing it. If you're trying to choose between whether to pick up Crimson Court or Color of Madness first, I'd recommend Color of Madness every time.

The description made this sound like it [i]came with[/i] and endless mode, but the [b]entirety[/b] of the content is an endless mode, mostly balanced to be done as post-game content. Which is unfortunate because it adds some nice districts that would be fun to try and get early on, if the Farmstead was actually a fleshed out area similar to the Crimson Court which [i]also[/i] had a true endless mode.

Even then (and with the mostly meh trinkets), I wanted to wait until I'd unlocked full endless mode before giving it a bad review. The problem is that because the Farmstead is a [b]completely[/b] different style of game than the rest of DD and there is [i]no[/i] in-game indication of how you should prepare, I basically just avoided doing any of the missions at all until recently.  Only to find out that the limited use per battle skills inexplicably weren't refreshing--was my game broken? The "single battle" buffs only lasted a single wave, but the "single battle" uses weren't coming back!

Yeah, no. Redhook decided to go with the lazy "git gud"mentality and because too many people were having fun making groups that dominated the early waves, the devs decided that the right way to address that was to arbitrarily change the meaning of "single battle" to mean whatever they liked best without giving the players an in-game way to know that. Not only is that really bad UX design, but it also limited the viable team comps for the Farmstead even [i]more[/i] than they were before! 

They had already added a mechanic to later levels to give more of a difficulty curve, so why not add a debuff to certain skills that made them limited use for the entire level? That way you 1) keep the consistency of what "one battle" means; 2) don't punish new players and lower level players; and 3) still give the higher level players a good challenge. But I guess anything that could possibly be fun or good game design would interfere with the "git gud" mentality.

If you want a good balance between punishing mechanics and fun content, stick with the base game and Crimson Court DLC. The only reason to pick this DLC up is if you enjoy several hours of endless grinding for mediocre rewards.

Darkest Dungeon: Color of Madness DLC

This expansion pack had the bad luck to have its release coincide with a tweak patch to the core game and a lash out from the Korean Steam community over the issuess with the Korean translation of the base game. The translation was, alegedly, awful, so this caused a lot of negative reivews. The patch was great but it fixed a long-standing exploit and people who were abusing it also review-bombed the game. So when looking up reviews for The Color of Madness you're very likely to run into negative reviews of it which don't actually have anything to do with it.

It's a great shame, because the expansion is excellent. The graphics and the sound are beautiful as usual, and they explore an area of Lovecraft's work not yet properly delved into in the base game. Darkest Dungeon never needed any praising on the art front, as even harshest critics have to take their hat off before the artists in Red Hook.

Mechanically, the DLC introduces great things. Someone knowledgeable could, and absolutely should, grumble about how a lot of what it introduced could have and should have been part of the core game in one way or another from early beta, but it's here now. So what do you get by purchasing this lovely little thing?

- A new area, the Farmstead, where you get to fight a series of long battles against waves of monsters, new bossess and many old ones. This is very fun post-game content for after you've played through the core game and Crimison Court. Don't ask me why the core game didn't have it's own rooms with longer fights, or why bossess dissapeared from it once you beat them several times. I didn't make it. But I sure suggested both those things, and this DLC finally brought them into the game.

- Cool new monsters which only appear in the new area. They're not terribly dangerous but play together well and do interesting and cool things. Red Hook have come a long way in designing monster encounters, and it shows. Or they found folks who're rather good at it. Why do these fun opponents only show up in the Farmstead, again, don't ask me. I neither made the game, nor raised the folks who did.

- A new wondering boss you can fight for special loot. In the best implementation of the concept yet, the new wondering boss will anounce itself before you pick a dungeon run, so you can either try to go chase after it, or avoid it as you see fit. It's an excellent fight and breathes a bit of life into the old core dungeons.

- Two brand new bossess exclusive to the Farmstead, as well as an opportunity to fight old ones. Well, it's more like three new bossess in the Farmstead, because one changes its form mid-fight. Great stuff!

- A whole slew of new trinkets, and they're more interesting than the old ones. The special currency used to buy them can also turn into a new kind of consumable item. I have always been dissapointed with a lot of design choices about the items, or trinkets as they are called, in DD as they explored a small part of the potential design space. Some of the CoM trinkets are among the most interesting and fun designs ever seen in the game. Ok, that's not saying much, but they're interesing enough they'd be right at home in a game with more interesting items in general.

- The Farmstead also features rooms with effects - that is, for the first time ever the room you have a fight in adds bonuses, maluses and special conditions to the fight. Again, try explaining to someone who hasn't purchased DD that every single room in it doesn't do this already and they'll have a hard time grasping why, but if you do get CoM at least you'll have one dungeon where (some) rooms are meaningful. I'm overjoyed to finally be able to experience this, even if the implementation, as usual, only covered a small % of interesting room effects. "A bit of something" is still a lot better than "none of something", expecially if it's something that's sorely lacking from the game.

- Four new Town buildings (districts) with several effect that have been asked for again and again by the community. I won't spoil the details.

- New uniqe and powerful quirks for your characters, and you don't even have to invest any in-game currency into "locking" them in place on your crew. Long time players will know just how great that is.

And while I might be forgetting something, this should be enough for you to know that this is a no-brainer purchase both if you do like Darkest Dungeon or if you've been dissapointed with it's relative sparseness and lack of content. The only real complaints about CoM would be - why wasn't most of this stuff part of the game already, and why did a lot of it get cordoned off into one area instead of applied to many other parts of the rather sparse core game?

But that's all the more reason to get CoM if you mean to play DD. It makes it a better, more interesting game. Absolute thumbs up!

EDIT: And I forgot to mention a very important thing which will interest long time players. Your characters can't die "for real" on a Farmstead run, and Farmstead runs don't advance the week. This gives your "overleveled" characters something useful and interesting to do while you develop your Hamlet. It can get you cool loot and trinkets, and several somewhat sucesful runs will give you enough "shards" to purchase a useful town district or interesting and powerful crystalline trinkets for your regular runs. You might hear talk that this DLC is only post-game content, but that's not true - it makes starting from scratch a lot more interesting and less frustrating than ever before.

As a consumer that has followed Darkest Dungeon for a couple years now, buying every edition and putting in many many hours on not only the PC version, but also the Switch version, it slightly pains me to see the various mixed reviews being made on this breath-of-fresh-air expansion. That being said, I will make this expansion review as non-biased as possible to entice players to give this DLC a try, because it is absolutely worth playing.

Disclosure: I received this product for free due to my participation in Red Hook's Beta Testing Stage.

Visuals/Sound Design:
-The DLC includes many new lighting enhancements, backgrounds, and enemies to the game, giving insight into the truly unique mood of the color of madness. The comet striking the farmstead, and the events that unfold the further you play are incredibly new and haunting to those who play. In this regard, the way this expansion looks is unlike anything you would ever see in the core game or the crimson court. 

-Likewise, Red Hook has added a plethora of new music to the farmstead, which are truly reminiscent of eldritch and otherworldly themes. New monologues are added by Wayne, so there are new instances of flavor to your play experience as well. 

Core Gameplay:
-Included here is a set of new bosses and standard enemies, with their own art, skill sets, and dark-souls-esque lore. Each of which are uniquely difficult and fun for every party composition. One particular fight is one that relies on not a battle of victory, but a battle of attrition and survival, a new concept that is well-made in this format.

-New area for missions. There are three mission types newly added to the farmstead: the short, apprentice level, wave-based mission that introduces players to the setting, gamestyle, and enemies. The second is the same, but adds a boss at the end for the more experienced players looking for better turnouts. 

-The last is the advertised endless mode, which is by far the best mission type included, which merits its own hyphen. This puts your party composition against a literal endless amount of enemies to fight. Now, despite this "endless" stigma tacked on to a hardcore turn-based game that adds permadeath, this game mode is exempt from that particular rule. As I threathen to spoil details, I will leave it at that. Likewise, there are many many suprises that will make the endless experience fun and rewarding. It should be fun and rewarding, you will most likely be spending a large amount of time on this mode, so you should be engrossed and rewarded for your time, which this mode definitely does. 

-The new shard currency system was also added, which can be used to buy incredibly useful trinkets at the trinket vendor, as well as new buildings, which are fairly lackluster to say the least except for two, and create a new shard dust provision to give you a very big edge in battle. You can collect these shards during farmstead missions, and the collection process is, in truth, a grind. There are many many trinkets and buildings, which are expensive to say the least, and after each *average* endless run in the farmstead, you may only afford one of them. So yes, it will be very difficult to collect them all.

In conclusion, if you are looking for a fresh new take on the formula Red Hook has given you, then you will absolutely love The Color of Madness. There is enough content here to give you hundreds of more hours of gameplay. When I personally look at pricetags, I think of the minds of the developers and their reasoning as to why they priced it that way. At $5.00, one would expect $5.00 of content, which to a lot of you doesn't seem like much content. But Red Hook has always provided and reached out to its community, moreso than any other developer I have ever followed (which are a lot), and have offered this great addition to Darkest Dungeon for the price that it is. I would consider Red Hook to provide more than $5.00 into this DLC, and I think you'll agree with me.

Red Hook missed the mark again. This DLC, much like Crimson Court, is a further deviation from the core gameplay experience and exasperates the negative aspects of the game.

Color Of Madness is intended to fill the role of an Endgame, whereby you endlessly kill enemies for as long as possible to obtain a high score. There are no leader boards or any form of acknowledgement outside of achievements. In-game rewards come in the form of new trinkets you can purchase. Additionally there is a new roaming boss that you may encounter.

The issue can be summarized as simply: grinding is not fun. The base game is designed for you to run 30~ minute dungeons; afterwards changing areas and classes to avoid feelings of repetition. Color Of Madness has you using the exact same party for hours at a time, creating a very monotonous experience.

It's not so offending given the price tag, but after playing the content through once I can say I will never revisit it.

The most directly Lovecraft-inspired of Darkest Dungeon's content, The Color of Madness reminds one very strongly of the short story "The Color out of Space", In which a meteorite falls upon a rural farmstead, bringing with it a malign presence from beyond. The key distinguishing feature of this presence is a unearthly glow of a color undefinable to the human experience. 

The Color of Madness chooses to render this color as a pale shade somewhere between teal and turquoise, the only color that escapes the Blasted Heath outside the Hamlet. Once, a kindly Miller and his wife lived there. Desperate from two years of failed crop yields, the Miller came to the Ancestor and begged him to save his farm. The Ancestor agreed to help, but in his typical cruel and self-serving fashion, brought the Miller and his farmhands only ruin- this time, not from the corruption seeping from beneath the manor house, but from somewhere else entirely. Now, the Farmstead's inhabitants have been corrupted by a spreading crystalline infestation, draining all color and life from them and transforming them into violent, crumbling husks- even the formerly inanimate scarecrows. 

A seed of interstellar hatred now grows in the Blasted Heath, horrifically warping time and space around it, and you can send your heroes on a series of quests into the new Farmstead region to investigate. After a small, fixed, introductory quest and a slightly longer one to face the Farmstead's first boss, you unlock the meat of this DLC: An endless dungeon where you face not only the Farmstead's creepy new enemies, the Husks, but also enter strangely-lit pocket dimensions which feature enemies and bosses from all of the other regions. The Farmstead has no layout per se, just fights, and more fights, and a progress bar that shows how close you are to your goal- or at least to the next boss fight. You will always fight the two Farmstead-specific bosses first. Like the Courtyard's special "Bloodlight" condition, the Farmstead features a variety of unique lighting effects that render Torch items useless, and carry with them certain buffs and debuffs for both your party and your enemies. Pass 200 kills in endless and a negative mutator will also be applied to your party, compounding the long haul further. There is also a new wandering boss that can also appear in the vanilla dungeon areas, and it is dangerous enough that the game will actually tell you where it is each week. It is by far the ugliest thing you will see in this game, and it is known only as... The Thing From The Stars. 

Crystal shards can be found in the Farmstead that can be traded with a new merchant at the trinket vendor, for new trinkets, some general, but mostly character specific ones. You can also use these and one other new resource, Memories, to construct some new districts- including rebuilding the Mill, which removes random hunger checks from your quests.

Like I said for the Crimson Court DLC, I do not recommend this for your first (or maybe even second) playthrough. Its content is entirely extraneous and will only confuse the player and detract from the feel of the main game.
That being said, the content is not entirely negative:
Pros:
New area with:
+ New enemies & bosses
+ New awesome esthetics
+ New haunting music
+ New game mechanics
Cons:
-	New area is entirely tacked on with almost no integration with the rest of the game, so much so that this area even has its own separate heroes you cant use anywhere else. No plot or introduction?
-	Expeditions to the new area do not advance the week. The week counter goes up and the missions randomize but you dont get any town events and no heroes in town have stress healed or diseases cured when committed in buildings. Why? Am I just loosing time?
-	You have to work really hard to get a mere couple special items worth of currency (which you can only get from the new area). With small amounts of normal resources on the side. Feels like a grind.
-	A few of said special items are nice? Nearly all have a tradeoff for using them. Not really worth it compared to the item sets you can get in the Crimson Court or even normally.
-	The new area just isnt. fun. Because the area is basically an endless mode it has been balanced such that you cant keep going forever, which means the characters you can take on such a mission are incredibly limited due to the difficulty and number of different enemies you need to adapt to in order to last any amount of time. 

How long do you want to run the same gauntlet with the same party of heroes for small amounts of currency to buy mostly mediocre items? Once they nerfed the strategy I was using I really havent wanted to bother to go back. Thats not a good sign.

I am really quite sad the endless mode isnt more fun because the art, lore, music, and premise of the Farmstead is really quite awesome and Id love to spend more time there if there was  well, anything to do.

Darkest Dungeon never disappoints me. Color of Madness is the third DLC to the game and it has its own mini-story to go with it, mostly taking place on a Farmstead where a comet from outer space has landed, bringing with it some eldritch horrors. This is what's contained in the DLC:

- 3 missions in a whole new area: the introductory Apprentice level mission, a longer Veteran level mission with a boss, and then the Endless Harvest mission (Darkest difficulty) that's technically endless, as the name suggests, but it's not just mindless wave after wave of enemies. It has some structure to it, where you'd battle new enemies for a couple of waves, then some enemies from one of the 4 maingame dungeons, and then it's usually a boss, and the further you go, the boss changes, although once you defeated the final boss of this DLC, the mission still continues and you can keep doing the whole thing anew if you so wish. The Endless Harvest mission doesn't get depleted and you can keep returning to it as many times as you want. All 3 of the missions behave more like making a stand in one area against incoming foes rather than traversing through dungeons.

- About half a dozen of new enemies to go to the theme of the new area, things such as possessed farm workers, possessed scarecrows, possessed horses, and so on. They all have their own unique behaviours, so you'll need to employ some new tactics.

- 4 new bosses (if I counted it correctly). One of these bosses is a wandering boss that randomly spawns in one of the 4 main areas of the game rather than in the DLC area. I've yet to find the wandering boss, but from among the others, I've found the two non-final bosses to have some interesting strategies under their sleeve, but the final boss is a bit too straightforward and mostly just spams powerful AoE attacks on the whole group rather than having new and interesting attacks.

- A new currency - Comet Shards. You only get these from the new area and they're required for purchasing special trinkets and constructing the new district buildings (see below).

- A good bunch of new trinkets that can only be bought with comet shards. Each hero class has a unique one for itself, and there are also some that can be equipped to anyone.

- A few new district buildings. These mostly just provide one additional effect to your supplies that you take to the missions (e.g. antivenom doesn't only cure blight but can now provide some resistance to it if used pre-emptively).

- A handful of really stunning music tracks that play in the battles of this new area. In my opinion, these new music tracks are some of the best the game has had so far. Do yourself a favour and give them a listen.

- Some new quirks have been added, including some quirks that are one-of-a-kind, which can only be gotten by one hero on a roster at a time and no more (these are usually very good quirks). 

In my opinion, this is a really nice DLC and well-worth getting for its small price tag, so long as you enjoyed the base game. I think it's a little less complicated and less punishing than the Crimson Court. Whereas Crimson Court added a lot of complexity and new mechanics to deal with, Color of Madness is mostly just enjoying yourself in constant combat without worrying about micromanaging additional mechanics. In that sense, if you didn't like Crimson Court due to the new mechanics it added, then you might still like Color of Madness.

Fun so far, the change in atmosphere and theme is really cool (I'm a huge fan of Lovecraft). Most of these negative reviews are from Koreans upset with translation issues and do not reflect on the quality of the game or content.

The Color Of Madness is a DLC for [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] that adds, among other things, a new region (Farmstead), new enemies (husks), new bosses, new trinkets, new buildings, a new, special currency and its main attraction... an "infinite" mode where you battle enemies... infinitely, both from this DLC as well from the past and the future. This DLC also contains some minor amount of lore, mainly showing how much of a grade A bastard your Ancestor was [spoiler]("My only regret is that I did not live to see that shoddy mill smashed to pieces by the miraculous bounty I reaped from beyond the void.").[/spoiler]

To access it you first you first have to beat 2 missions that serve as a sort of "Introduction" to the infinite mission you'll be able to play. They are... ok. Mostly just showing you the hopes while also throwing some challenges at you. When you're done with them you get to the real cheese of this DLC: The Infinite Mode!! Where you're thrown against infinite (huh) hordes of enemies and bosses in search of the new currency of this DLC: Comet Shards (along with a harder to get currency: Memories). Get ready to throw your hardened traumatized veterans into the impossible blue cracked fields of a cursed farm in search of those! It'll almost be totally worth it!

Seriously now, the Comet Shards allow you to buy new special DLC trinkets in a new section of the Nomad Wagon (some of which possess never seen before properties), build special districts and they can even be used as a dust in battle to make your Heroes stronger for some time. Beware, though, for the dust has different reactions if a hero keep using it and it also debuffs your Hero in some way. I don't really use them as I'd rather use the shards for other stuff but I can see them being useful. Also, a problem that I had with the districts is simply how long one of them takes to be built. This one building takes 10 very hard to get "Memories" (the second new currency in the DLC) to be made... Requiring many hours of grind. Rivalling even The Great Crimson Court's Trinket Hunt.

The Infinite Mission is the main attraction in this DLC and it delivers... although not in the way I expected it to. There's not much to be said about the whole "infinite" part of it. You're fighting old and new enemies and bosses... infinitely (of course it's not infinitely, you can stop at any point and just escape with your accumulated rewards). Sometimes the Farmstead's Lighting will change and effects will be applied both to Heroes as well as enemies, and after a while enemies will get stronger. Due to the way the Farmstead works (and the whole "constant battles" thing), if you want to get far without problems you won't have many team compositions available to you. Heroes with great versatility are the best ones that you can use here. Heroes with poor versatility or that can't target many different enemy spots will make you suffer, which is a shame, considering the DLC adds so many interesting trinkets that can barely be used thanks to this.

The music tracks are, again, amazing. Stuart continues to make a great job. My fave is Blasted Heath. It goes well with the whole "a terrible thing fell on these lands" theme and the infinite horde of half-crystalized enemies marching towards you. If I had to complain about something is that they can be considered as "repetitive" in a way, but this isn't a problem inherent to the music, [b]it comes from the DLC.[/b]

I consider the art in this DLC the epitome of Darkest Dungeon. The colors on the Farmstead changing with meaning, the hauntingly beautiful glimmer of the shards and the stress symbol mixed with it, the "impossible" backgrounds when lost between space and time... I simply [b]LOVED[/b] it.

While this DLC can feel repetitive and boring in some aspects, I really enjoyed it. Testing my Heroes against the unstoppable horde of Husks and trying to see how far I could go before everything fell apart was a fun deed. Getting my crystals and buying unfathomable trinkets for my Heroes along with building neat new districts was nice. More goals for the endless quest.

Good DLC!

[spoiler]"The poor Miller  [b]thrice a victim[/b]. The seasons took his livelihood, I took his land, and now, [i][u][b]uncountable[/b][/u][/i] years later, [u]the comet has taken his HUMANITY[/u]. My only regret is that I did not live to see that [i]s h o d d y[/i] mill [b]SMASHED[/b] to pieces by the miraculous bounty I reaped from beyond the [i]void[/i]".

[h1] The Color of Endless Mode [/h1]

Once you have spent enough time with the base game, it becomes truly captivating how Red Hook studios yet again introduces elements that twist existing game mechanics. Just a little bit, yet enough to force player to take a new look at the task on hand. It has to be stated that Color of Madness has flatout less content than Crimson Court, but its price is lowered properly to match. With this in mind what new horrors loom in the darkness?

[b] The Harvest awaits [/b]
Color of Madness introduces new area  the Farmstead with complete set of new enemies and environment specific curios and items. DLC introduces husks  remains of Miller and his unfortunate workers stuck beyond space and time, warped beyond recognition. DLC also introduces 3 new bosses: the aforementioned Miller, the Thing from Stars  eldritch horror from outer space, and the Sleeper  cosmic malignance that awaits the player in the endless mode.

Why yes. Color of Madness in essence simply adds endless mode into the game. This is only type of mission that can be undertaken in farmstead. Entirety of gameplay revolves around fighting wave upon wave of enemies as each kill painfully slowly fills the reward bar. After reaching certain amount there will be a moment of respite and hopefully a curio to heal body or mind (luckily there are no harmful ones), once bar is filled first tier of rewards is guaranteed. Then you can try to reach next tier again and then again, however long your party can last. While base game is all about survival this DLC is plain war of attrition where you are the only side affected by it.

[b] The little things [/b]
Contrary to the Crimson Court, Color of Madness has almost no impact on game world beside the Thing from the Stars roaming the land. Each week it is shown where you will have a chance to face the Thing, allowing you to avoid it at your leisure if you choose to do so. Beside that it is almost exclusively quality of life additions. Stage coach and nomad wagon gain a crystalline twist. There come mercenaries who are always level 6 maxed out heroes, providing you with endless supply of quality cannon fodder. As everything in the game they come at a price - they can be used only in Farmstead and will tax you a fraction of shards you managed to gather. Nomad wagon on the other hand gets a crystal hungry counterpart that will provide unique crystalline trinkets that will greatly aid your ventures into the Farmstead. New DLC is grind turned up to eleven but wagon trinkets create progression system of sorts  the more you do, the better trinkets you get so you can harvest even more.

Artwise Farmstead is as lovely as any other part of the game if new art is somewhat less numerous since you dont really get to walk anywhere, rather stand and fight while reality bends around you. It has to be noted that while Lovecraftian themes where ever-present in the game, for the first time Red Hook were this direct with drawing inspiration. DLC is literally named after short H.P. Lovecraft story.

New DLC is, if modest, simply a fine addition. If you enjoy Darkest Dungeons combat you get a place to truly let loose. As color of madness change you can meet enemies from all regions and later even any hard-tier boss. There is a twist though, you must build your party to last. Sheer lethality and full backpack of supplies wont do when minds of your party snap like twigs. In the long run it is often stress that is the real killer here.

Another fantastic edition to one of the best RPG games in the last 10 years. The endless kills is crazy! it's like taking crack, and giving it crack. I mean DD is already an intense game, how do you add pure intensity to the intensity? They did it! This game is so good, and the price is so ridiculously cheap for the excellent content, that I sincerley hope they make a Darkest Dungeon 2 in the future, a whole new game with a brand new plot. Just love this stuff, the narration, the intelligent vocabulary, the complex sophistication, and the insanely difficult challenge, with the novelties of stress and the implementation of perma death. The new content is perfect, love the farm and the endless kills.

I love the base game, and the crimson court expansion, but I am afraid I found this kind of boring. It doesn't add much in terms of story, but more importantly playing the color of madness dungeon is a dull grind. Gone is the tense fear and anticipation of wandering through a dungeon wondering if each step will trigger a trap or an attack, instead you get a constant predictable stream of enemies slowly grinding you down until you choose to exit. 

Its an experiment on the darkest dungeon formula, which for me failed. I personally hope any future expansions will stick to the tried and tested formula we all know and love and love to hate.
Darkest dungeon is a good game, the expansions are totally skippable though. I might go as far as to say they actually detract from the original game.

The Colors of Madness was a fantasticly fun DLC....for about 2 days.  Then, as has been a trend, Red Hook seemed to jump at attention when people started to compain the usual "It's TOO EASY!".  Those people complaining, as usual, seemingly mostly being twinks who have played upwards of hundreds of hours, jumping into the DLC content with estates in the hundreds of weeks, with their twinked out parties of min-maxed heroes and trinket combos. 

The sad part being, I impulse bought this almost IMMEDIATELY after watching several streamers give it a try, and watching them sing the praises of how fun and well balanced they thought the new content was, especially after how much of an absolute slog the Crimson Court content could be.  Fun?  In the Darkest Dungeon again?  Sign me up, right?  Shame that it seems to be getting gnawed away at by the usual "git gud" crowd.  You people know who you are.  Go ahead and downvote this, noone cares what you think anymore.

That aside, let's go into the meat of the content of the DLC itself; you can expect, if you are starting from a fresh file:
#1)  One (1) "apprentice" level dungeon, that introduces the Farmstead and some of the new creatures, in a "mini-run" of sorts.
#2)  One (1) "veteran" level dungeon, that introduces the format of the meat of the DLC, the Endless Mode, but in a sample sized, 3-"wave" portion that culminates in one of the major new bosses of the area.  It is a very, VERY well executed introduction to how things will be working, the "shifting colors" torch-light mechanic, the "mid-wave break and resupply", and how progress and rewards are done.
#3)  An endless amount of the Endless Harvest mode, a "Darkest Difficulty" dungeon which essentially takes #2, and makes THE MEATGRINDER go on until you click the "retreat" button, at which point (at the time of writing this) you are given an absolutely free pass out of the current dungeon run, even during combat, with no chance to fail like usual retreats.  A randomized boss is selected from a small pool every few waves to try to prevent you from reaching the next tier of rewards, mostly being the "shards" that are traded in town for new buildings or (mostly gimmicky) trinkets.
#4)  An endless amount of a new "wandering boss" that has a chance to show up on one of the major 4 properties during any week.  Rewards are possibly unique trinkets, unique quirks, and even more shards to trade.  He's a good boss, with a couple of neat gimmicks, and even if you run into him in an apprentice dungeon, a solid party with a plan should be able to take him down.

All in all, it's a solid amount of content...except at the same time, please note up there that this means only one apprentice and one veteran outing into the new area is given to you, then it's "almost all endgame party all the time".  That's right, it's even more Champion-centric than Crimson Court was.  To alleviate (?) this, they do give you the option of hiring up to 6 Champion-grade "mercenaries" at a time...except they're all the same as the kind of "fresh off the wagon" hires you would get, AND they take some of your earned shards from you per-mercenary-per-run on top of it.  So while you can TECHNICALLY still "enjoy" The Farmstead while you're still in the lower levels of a newer game file, it'll be with parties of generics.  (If this was to keep people away from getting the new trinkets early, it's a funny way of doing so, since most of the new ones are gimmicky or even generally outclassed by what you would get late-game, or from Crimson Court.)

The art and music are great, as usual, and as stated above, the CORE CONCEPT of the DLC is a solid one.  But in the end, it comes down to this being a DLC that is mostly there for people already at endgame to challenge themselves.  Conventially, if you are at a point where you're able to enter the Endless Harvest over and over again, to win enough to trade for all the new goods available, you're proabably already ready to head into the Darkest Dungeon and just beat the game.  The only reason you would have for doing it at that point is wanting the endgame to go on forever.  And if that's what you're into, great!  This is for you.  If you're looking for something to supplement/run parallel to a "from scratch" playthrough...not so much.  
Oh, and not so much if you don't enjoy, as of writing this, the addition of such things as just plain empty "middle finger" rewards rooms.  Or the Crimson Court Croc.  Yes, that.  We all laughed, and made jokes about "at least the Croc isn't in this one".  Welp.

As much as I love Darkest Dungeon, I can't recommend this. It punishes you for not going a very specific build, more so if you don't have the shieldbreaker. I wanted an endless mode that I could put the to the test my knowledge of the game; instead, I paid for two shieldbreakers, jester, and a vestal. Great music, however.
Can't believe the number of people trashing the DLC because of Korean translation issues (It's being handled) or their modded games not working (seriously people...)

A wealth of content that is a steal at only 5 bucks.
There is certainly more to this expansion than meets the eye, but I don't want to spoil anything.
The new endless mode is brutally difficult, but also greatly rewards clever team composition and if you're someone who has already beaten the base game but gets a little scared about the time and death constraints of stygian or doesn't want to start all over, it's a welcome challenge.

I'm a big fan of Darkest Dungeon, with almost 500 hours played and 100% achievements.
I didn't like Crimson Court and gave it a negative review.
On the other hand, Color of Madness is great. It adds the endless harvest, which is a great place for veteran players to test themselves. The new trinkets are interesting, ranging from mediocre to awesome.
Unlike Crimson Court, this DLC doesn't shove the new content in your face at every step, even if you activate it too early. It just stays there as an additional challenge.

Great value for a few euros.

The Color of Madness is a good idea that could have been so much more.

Similar to Crimson Court, it tries to put a twist on the core formula and provides a unique region/mode to farm for endgame trinkets.

And like Crimson Court, you will see most of the content on-hand pretty quickly.

I do see the appeal of the mode but it's just not for me. Almost requiring a Jester to manage stress severely limits your team composition. In addition, some bosses requiring certain positions to be hit reduces the team flexibility further and punishes you if you attempt an unconventional composition (looking at you, Miller).

For its price, what's on offer may appeal to some but it's just not enough to merit sinking any more than a few hours of your time into.

I would have preferred if the endless mode warped you to other dungeons (briefly) for curio interaction/stress heal/roaming boss interaction and potentially more of a reason to use the Crimson Court content. More importantly, a reason to reuse Darkest Dungeon Quest backgrounds and monsters (that are mostly one-and-done affairs). But instead, its a tredmill and slot machine in one. There are so many ways to make this mode appear fresh and its all underutilized.

Once again, the Art and Music are incredible and may be worth the purchase alone. Otherwise, I got the trinkets I wanted and hung up my hat. A fun experiment but an experience that feels over before it truly starts.

I can't give this a thumbs up. This would have been a much better DLC had this just been a new dungeon addition. Instead it is just an endless mode.. and while I do like the art and new monsters I just can't help but wish it was an actual dungeon to crawl through. I've had this DLC since buying DD but I rarely use it because endless mode is just not for me.

If you have a love of the core game than this is a good addition.  otherwise... eh, wait for a sale.

The mechanics here sort of highlight the limitations of the combat system and forces you into a VERY specific team composition.  You Have to have a Vestal for healing, you HAVE to have a Jester for stress, and you NEED something to break guard if you want to get by the Miller boss.

Also to save you all a big headache.  If one of your characters kickes it, they are not permanently dead BUT you do lose any items they had unless you finish the fight he died in.

This isn't necessarily the same type of DLC as Crimson Court is - CC added much more of a story, additional gameplay elements, and a whole new questline.

Color of Madness is more of a "if you wanted an occasional fun new challenge, here's an endless version".  I really enjoy it - the different style of gameplay is fun, the trinkets are kinda neat, new roaming boss is quite the fight.  But it's not a "new storyline, lots of new content" sort of DLC.  I personally like Crimson Court trinkets way more, and play the Farmstead only when I'm in the mood for an "Endless Quest" type of run.

There is one very notable perk though (which I hope they don't nerf away because it's a big reason I still play the Endless Harvest): one you complete the "storyline" of Color of Madness and get to the endless portion, there's no death.  Your heroes can still "die" in the quest, but instead of actually dying they just disappear for a week and come back massively stressed out.  (You will lose equipped trinkets though, so watch out.)  This is nice because I feel like i can test the limits of my heroes, weird party combos, etc. without worrying about losing my Level 6 folks.  (Mercenaries help a lot with this too.)

Overall, while it's not nearly as content and lore-heavy as Crimson Court, it's still a fun DLC.  Snag the "Endless Harvest Bosses Only" mod for extra adventure!

Some preliminiary impressions from a couple hours of play.

Just as with the Crimson Court, if you are a new player don't bother with this. It will only make the already difficult learning curve even more challenging and most likely cause you to wipe your runs and have to start over.

If you are a veteran and love the combat than this is the dlc for you. It's all about trying to get as far as you can in endless battles, and the nerfs that have hit just about everybody will make you rethink a lot of your tried and true strategies. They call them balance changes but if you look at the patch notes its alomst all nerfs except giving everybody (except houndmaster, apprently he needed negative crit chance) 1-2% crit chance and a buff when they do crit. So far it has made most of the characters feel weaker but maybe I just haven't adapted yet. It's pretty annoying though when you try to do something you could before and can't, like hit somebody in rank 3 with rampart, and then you have to change your whole strategy on the fly but I'm sure I'll learn.

The new enemy types are fun and really bring back the sense of danger running into a new enemy type brought before you knew what they all did. However I must say I prefer the exeprience of running dungeons to this new mode. I love the balancing act of when to use what items, what route to take, etc. A lot of the strategy is lost here as it's just load up on as many supplies as you can get your hands on to try to last as long as possible with no incenitve to leave space for other things.

The new vendor and buldings are neat but nothing amazing. Not really a lot to say about them.

Overall it's great to get more Darkest Dungeon. The experience is by no means perfect but for $5 I think it's well worth a buy if you want more to do in this great game.

The main game is great.  This DLC, not so much.

- Endless mode is not fun.   It doesn't have the flexibility of normal dungeon runs, so it ends up being incredibly repetitive.
- One main new building, which is a massive grind to get.  By the time you finally finish the grind, the building won't be much use to you because you're either already done with the main game or you're at a point where carrying food doesn't really affect you much.
- Most of the new trinkets aren't very good.

While I'm not a big fan of throwing the corpses of my fallen heroes I spent hours cautiously nurturing into formidable allies into a bottomless pit of dangerous grind for some shiny blue rocks, this DLC is what I would recommend the most. If you want to spend money on DLC for Darkest Dungeon, this is the one to get. You get heaps of content from a relatively cheap DLC (at least in comparison to the other options). 
The new region features an endless fighting phase that explores an alien farmstead, filled with more tenacious foes than your usual dungeon, with the goal of determining how many enemies you can fell in hopes of obtaining Comet Shards before your team wipes, or you retreat and suffer the stress of loss. Although it's more survivable than the Courtyard of The Crimson Court DLC, it still provides a considerable challenge for those seeking these new useful trinkets. 
If endless dungeons are not your thing, you can leave it untouched and reap the benefits of the District system (buildings within your hamlet you can repair for very welcomed boosts) and new quirks for your heroes. A very worthwhile purchase if you're a big fan of Darkest Dungeon.

I didnt really like this expansion. Just a lot of grinding a new area called the farmstead for subpar items that are worst than the ones from the crimson court expansion (which was actually worthy of being called an expansion). But i do love Darkest Dungeon so just to support the developers alone i am glad i bought this "expansion". But if youre wondering if its worth it on its own merit, its not. So overall, all things considered i must thumb this down. But if you appreciate Red Hook Studios and the great classic they have made, you should buy it anyway.

If you love the combat of The Darkest Dungeon, then The Colour of Madness DLC adds an endless wave mode with unique trinkets, currency and enemies, meaning you can really hone your tactical abilites in the new Farmstead area.

The best part!? After completing the introduction quest any heroes that die during an Endless Harvest run aren't gone forever, allowing you to really try out some interesting team combinations, that you usually wouldn't do because of the risk of losing valuable heroes you've invested time and money on. 

Although if you're just starting your descent into the Darkest of Dungeons, then i would recommend that you wait abit before buying the Colour of Madness, as its content is aimed more towards players in the endgame instead of the newer ones. Then again should you decide to buy it, remind yourself that overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer...

It's good.. but it's not worth more than $5.  It really is a straightforward addition to the game.  Another mini boss.  Some more trinkets.  Some more buildings in the blueprint menu.  And horde mode.  

If you loved Darkest Dungeon then you should absolutely grab it because it makes the game more enjoyable.  But it isn't like Crimson Court.  It's just a little add on.  Bigger than a mod, smaller than a proper expansion.  

I can't fault them for it but I think we were excited for another Crimson Court sized expansion to the game so we were all a little let down and the reviews reflect that.

Its pretty good and a must have, even if you don't care for the endless quest. Plus, the music is fantastic!

Below are some details about this dlc, includes minor spoilers:

[spoiler]The main challenge of this DLC is to assemble a single team that can slay 300+ enemies in its endless mode. If you manage that feat you can easily buy every trinket and building within a couple of runs. You might fail a few times but It really doesn't take much and you get some rewards. Once you accomplish this feat you're essentially done with the Farmstead. Rack your brains and make it happen.

Dying here is still not fine cuz even though you get your hero back, you will lose your trinkets until you recover them from the Shrieker. But on the plus side you can suicide heroes with useless trinkets to painlessly get the number of lost trinkets up to 8, which will trigger the Shrieker kill quest to retrieve other more important trinkets you lost elsewhere. You can also do this to farm Shrieker's exclusive quirks.

You can test out various strats using Farmstead-exclusive level 6 heroes that will become available from the Stage Coach. They will steal some of your shards though.

Some of the trinkets are generally great, but most of them aren't all that, many are tailored for the endless mode so have a look at them while devising your strategy.

Also adds a wandering boss that drops a few exclusive trinkets, you can see where he might be lurking on the overworld map. He's pretty cool.

Gives you a little extra to do with some solid rewards. It's a neat addition to the game and provides a fun experience without breaking everything else.

The music is good, the setting is good, and you can always bypass it or step away from the content whenever you'd like.
It's a worthy addition.
Don't forget to name your characters after your loved ones, so you can hate yourself just that little bit more when you inevitably die.

The DLC adds something I personally find very interesting, and that the game lacked: an endless mode. I believe its well designed, its not balance breaking (cough* cough* Crimson Court), it has a really great soundtrack and overall expands the game. I don't see why someone shouldn't get this when they buy Darkest Dungeon.

[i] The poor Miller... countless times the victim... [/i]
This DLC is insanely good.
The new bosses are fun and challenging, the trinkets are useful and unique.
The meat of this DLC is the Endless Harvest, an endless mode. I honestly loved it trying to get all achievements, and figuring out which party compostitions work best.
After you unlock the endless, it'll make your game easier (due to the recruitable mercs and trinkets, and the fact that your heroes can't die, they just leave for a week) unlike the Crimson Court which is just pure suffering.

The pre-patch update has been interesting. It nerfed some of the more OP classes (flagellant, houndmaster) and buffs the weaker classes to be stronger (Grave robber, Leper, Vestal). They also buffed critical hits. Back in Early access, crit statagies were popular but died when they nerfed crit rate. Well Crit rate has been buffed a bit, as well as crit buffs added. Steady damage is still very viable, there is just a second way to. 

As a modder, this patch and DLC has been great. It adds in so many effects and keywords that I can play with to make better and more interesting mods. In base content that it comes with, it is kind of lacking. It has 3 plot quests, one wandering boss, and an endless mode. 

The main content that you get from this is the trinkets. The new trinkets are interesting and can help in many ways. 

Overall I would recommend it due to the price point.

Color of Madness and Crimson Court are both masterpieces in artistic terms. Darkest Dungeon already stands out with its unique music and art style, full of personality and charisma. Color Of Madness takes this to another level. While I personally dont find the Farmstead and the Husk as unique as the Courtyard and the Bloodsuckers, they are still pretty cool in their own way. Stuart Chatwood outdid himself once again, and "All Things Must Come" is my personal favorite track in this DLC.

But what about the content itself? Color of Madness is an endless mode where a comet's impact has created a breach in time and space, introducing a new challenge. This challenge brings a unique area, enemies, bosses, mechanics, and trinkets, all masterfully executed. There isnt much more I can say without spoiling the entire DLC. It features two introductory missions, a small but nice story, and then its all about the endless mode and its mechanics.

It's an amazing addition, thats all.

This expansion is a bit tricky to review. It's very reasonably priced for what it is, but I'm torn on whether it really adds to the game.

The farmstead includes fun new enemies and doesn't consume a week to go to it!
...but the new trinkets you can purchase with the loot are for the most part either situational or underwhelming.

The farmstead is a great setting and has a unique new feel to it!
...but it doesn't really feel like it fits with the rest of the lore. Even the narration seems rather uncharacteristic of the Ancestor's personality. Spoiler: [spoiler]while the Ancestor narrates the rest of the game seeming like he's conflicted in his decisions, his narrations for the Miller don't hide his contempt at all.[/spoiler]

There are new districts that give buffs to consumables, gem stacking, and can even eliminate hunger checks!
...but by the time you can afford them they're pointless.

There are dedicated heroes you can recruit solely for farmstead missions that don't add to your roster!
....but a full party of them will nearly halve the amount of loot you get, and since shards are slow to gather and farmstead missions can easily last 1-2 hours, using them makes an already grind-y part even more so.

There are a few things that I unequivocally appreciate though, and they're the reason I'm giving it an overall positive review.
[list][*]The new wandering mini-boss is great and gives some seriously strong perks and loot when you beat it, while striking the right balance of fairness and challenge. You can avoid it altogether just by watching where it is, but once you're seen some of the perks you'll find yourself hunting for it.
[*]The new perks are unique and interesting, and some of them can really elevate a character.
[*]The Farmstead is entirely optional, so if you decide it isn't your thing you can just avoid it and it won't attack the rest of your game.[/list]

Overall it's a fun diversion, albeit feeling a little like it was shoehorned in. I picked this and Crimson Court up for another run at Darkest Dungeon after playing vanilla back when it came out. I got them both on sale and at the price I'm glad I did - but I'm not sure I'd call it a "great" expansion so much as a bit of a bonus.

If I had to be honest, I feel this along with CC helped me genuinely feel what this game is meant to be like for a new player.

Before I bought Darkest Dungeon, I basically spoiled 99% of the game for myself from watching gameplay on Youtube and browsing the wiki. I've never been one to care about spoilers so I didn't really think too much about it until later, but I ended up tainting my experience of DD; I learned what to expect for the mobs, the boss fights, the town events, and as a result it just didn't hold as much excitement when I knew what to do. I feel I really missed out. 

As a result, when CoM was released, I made a vow to jump in blind and explore the content for myself without spoiling anything. I got to experience, in its entirety, that sense of mild panic and confusion when I faced the Farmstead, and [spoiler] when my party got its shit kicked in fighting the Thing from the Stars, the fucking aborted love child of Fanatic and  Shambler [/spoiler]. CoM helped me understand how the game was meant to feel for a fresh player, and while I know all of this is subjective, I feel CoM was worth the money for me, and would definitely recommend it for any  DD player.

TL;DR Self-spoiling the game killed my DD experience, CoM saved it.

Endless Harvest, not so endless fun. This DLC gives you 
1) A new zone with a mandatory apprentice quest (tutorial) to unlock a mandatory veteral quest (boss) and finally unlock the darkest quest 'Endless Harvest'. You farm crystals here.
2) A roaming boss who caps PROT after he gets under 45% HP, making Shieldbreakers and Grave Robbers even more useful. He always drops crystals but will rarely drop a Memory or a special Trinket
3) A few districts bought with crystals and a district bought with memories, a guaranteed drop from the second boss fight in the endless harvest (and rare drop from the new roaming boss).
4) A second shop that only trades new trinkets for crystals.

The thing is, the Endless Harvest gets old really fast. There are people who like to go for huge records in the thousands of kills but the most you want to get is 300 for the steam achievement and that's it. The money reward does not increase past a certain point. Doing Endless Harvest missions is useful because it does not advance the week so you can farm money fast. Besides that... It's a chore. Your heroes do not gain quirks while doing this quest either, probably because it would make getting good quirks combos would be easier and Red Hook gets utterly triggered by the word easy and its derivations.

The roaming boss is a chore as well. You might want to farm him for his rare trinkets if you want to collect'em all but frankly they're pretty garbage trinkets.

There's only two districts worth the hassle. The Mill (no more hunger checks) and the one that increases your gem-stacking limit by one. It might not sound so great but it applies to two valuable gems that are normally limited to one per stack.

Out of all the trinkets you buy with crystals, only a handful are not complete garbage.

And to top it all, Red Hook recently decided to make the Endless Harvest more of a chore because they didn't like the fact people were able to get more than 1000 kills in the Endless Mode.

I honestly feel that this makes early to mid game a lot easier, mostly thanks to expendable mercenaries and OP trikents.
I HIGHLY recommend getting the shieldbreaker for both endless, and for The Cunt From The Stars.

Mostly disappointed with this one. 2 mandatory AoE bosses in the first stages of endless require either AoE healing or AoE dodge if you don't want to risk ending the run just after 3 rounds, which means your rank 4 is locked either by Vestal or Antiquarian. The whole idea of "enemies become stronger" present in nearly all games with endless modes isn't really here:
- Enemies stay at the same level and don't get any progressive increase in stats via torch modifiers and whatnot. 
- You just get a predermined penalty after 200 kills which you can see on the map and therefore decide if you want to go or wait for the other one.
- Those first 2 bosses are actually the ones that will determine whether you can keep going. If you handle them (returning to AoE dodge or healing mentioned above) then you can, and nearly forever, regardless of reflections and such, until you get an unlucky deathblow or just can't stomach doing the same thing anymore. 
The infamous "battle limited skills" patch was a prime example of balancing the normal game around DLCs and failing to do so, and additionally ruining the experience of the DLC even further. Shard dust isn't used in endless, it's used to cheese bosses with 7 stacks of Bolster/Revenge/Plague Doc vapours and it's undoubtedly more broken than activating Revenge in every wave in endless. I don't really understand why the subject of 1000 kills was such a touchy matter that the devs had to push the Vestal/Antiquarian/Jester meta even further! Since the endless waves are long battles, stacking battle-long buffs or charging Finale finally saw a new use, but devs said "no, keep them only for bosses, AGAIN, or just take a Shieldbreaker with that OP crystal trinket." Heroes like Leper or Abomination were never crit-heavy or simply popular due to loads of restrictions and disadvantages they have (and I say it as a Leper player) but they still had to get nerfed overall just because of endless kill scores. And yet they decided not to do anything to Man-at-Arms who can do everything especially with his new busted Bolster and -33% stress from crit that procs from riposte too and stacks twice. Or with Shieldbreaker who can attack anything from anywhere with high base damage, crit and natural armor break. Priorities... 
Among other things: filters in the waves (especially red) are also terrible and eat your eyes away, probably intentionally trying to get you afflicted in real life. Standard Farmstead torch has double-dipping stress increases, both from the stated +10% stress modifier and hidden parameters like on Crimson Court blood torch, which is why THE SEEDS and comet boss horror spam are so absurd.
Results: very repetitive, meta-heavy experience with weird balancing decisions that still failed to prevent the damned "1000 kills" self-imposed challenge but allowed for ez 500 crit finale dmg final boss kills.

I find that this DLC embodies all of the worst of what Darkest Dungeon has to offer. It's very unclear how you're meant to provision or who you're meant to bring and, upon braving the 1st quest, the location seems totally manageable. However, the 2nd visit introduces a plethora of new mechanics which weren't introduced in the 1st encounter. It seems that the only way you're meant to understand the Farmstead is by sending a squad or two to their death or, alternatively, scour the wiki for what happens before you enter. 1st encounter had no resting so I assumed it was safe to avoid food, the 2nd visit left me at a required rest without warning. The 1st encounter introduced the basic enemies I should expect from the zone, the 2nd encounter introduced a mechanic that grabbed enemies from other areas which my composition was unprepared for. I wiped a full level 4 party with 4 sets of my best trinkets. Not because I played poorly, but because I wasn't given any information to prepare with, even after entering the zone once before. 

This DLC really highlights the largest failing of Darkest Dungeon, in that the only way to prepare for a zone is to essentially throw a team to the wolves with a very high likelihood they'll simply die. Not because you played poorly, but because you didn't bring enough food or anti-venom. The DLC offers very little in terms of interesting additions and insular design that makes it feel entirely worth avoiding. There's little compositional variety and the infinite mode gets old super quick while providing zero content outside of itself. 

On the other hand the artists have, as always, done amazing work and provided some beautiful new enemies. While I think this was a swing and a miss, plenty of players will find the infinite mode engaging and enjoyable if they can get past the unfortunate introduction to the area.

Color of Madness adds an endless mode, that while I consider not that fun, is good if you like that sort of thing. Fortunately, it adds another way to interact with a lot of the dlc content by adding an optional wandering miniboss that you can choose to go hunt down, and it honestly gives you a goal and something to go after  besides just leveling all your heroes up to 6 after you beat the game. The couple normal missions leading up to the endless are fine too, but the highlight for me is the miniboss, which, while difficult, isn't game breaking, and you can build a team designed around killing it because it tells you what area it's in so you can anticipate when you'll run into it. With drops from this miniboss, you can still get a lot of the trinkets and buildings this dlc adds, although at a slower rate, but it feels more fun and balanced this way, because it feels like I'm doing normal missions  but with the added bonus of occasionally running into a challenging miniboss in the halls at random, you can't predict where it will be like a normal boss, but you can tell if you might run into it during your mission, so it's just the right level of preparedness and randomness, and it doesn't really detract from the base game at all, it still feels like darkest dungeon but now you have a strong miniboss that you may encounter if you want to go to the specific area it's in, but with great rewards and not impossible difficulty. Honestly, this dlc just adds to the game, and if you do interact with the dlc content you will be rewarded for it, and if you don't, well you don't actually have to interact with it, it's not forced on you like crimson court.
Edit: This dlc also adds many minor additions to the base game, like some new quirks, some of them just added to the basic quirk pool you can get from normal curios or mission ends, some pretty good, some fairly bad.

Darkest Dungeon was already a crushingly difficult game, but the recent patch and DLC has flipped the balancing on its rear and made it even more punishing. The DLC makes a lot of changes, and almost all of them make the game more difficult and overall make it less fun.  Enemies now CRIT with an absurd frequency, now enemies that have 1 damage stress attacks are doing crits, which Ive never seen before this update.

Enemies also now bully and single out a specific character, typically the healer. Never had this experience on Radiant (easiest) difficulty before, but now its absurd. Battles quickly shift into stressfull bouts of desperately trying to keep the healer alive while your party continually misses every attack. Accuracy/dodge/miss system has been changed too, again favoring irrational difficulty. Any of my party members that dont have at least 100 accuracy miss half of their attacks, even against enemies with 0 dodge.

New quirks have been added, and lo and behold they make the game even more infuriating. Recruits now have 2-3 negative quirks upon recruitment, and one good perk. It used to be an even 1 good 1 bad split. The RNG for hero creation is also broken, as currently 9 out of 11 of my roster have the negative quirk light sensitive, this is unprecedented, Ive never seen a perk occur with such frequency, another indication of broken RNG.

The good quirks they added range from lackluster to downright worthless, the only one Ive seen so far in my game that was worthwhile was one that gave 25% stress healed, which is still pretty dissapointing. But the bad quirks have been intensified to an asinine degree. Remember slow reflexes, the -1 speed perk? Bad enough on its own, but theres a new one called "fading" that DOUBLES the speed debuff to -2 and also throws in -5 dodge. 

Thats the equivilent of THREE negative perks all wrapped up in one, two slow reflexes and one clumsy perk. Awesome! Considering recruits now start with 3 bad quirks, youll be spending most of your gold stuffing the sanitarium full trying to get your squad to not suck so damn much, enjoy.

The RNG has been completely botched. Enemies that normally had an extremely rare crit chance now proc crits ten times more often, which doesnt sound like a "minor change" to me, its a total overahaul. The "critsmas" crit mechanic they added does NOT work as advertised, or even as they intended, youve been warned. Heroes miss way more attacks than they should, and the most damning piece of evidence is that I surprise enemy groups on EVERY single battle, a small mercy. Normally surprising mobs would happen only semi-often under certain circumstances, but now it happens every single time, regardless of my torch light level, trinkets or heroes in party. I tested it with 0 torch light, and the two battles I encountered, both times enemies were surprised.

To me that indicates just how much the RNG has been botched. The update/DLC has changed things well beyond their intended effects, Im not sure if the devs are even aware of it or understand how/why its happened that way. 

This purchase has been the biggest rip-off Ive ever had the misfortune of spending money on. Not because its money wasted, its only $5, but because its ruined one of my favorite games. Darkest Dungeon just a week ago was a difficult but manageable game that was never short of challenging encounters. Its been twisted into a sadistic and punishing game that will make you  want to rip your hair out. The game always had tempermental RNG, but now its downright broken and completely sporadic, following no set heuristics or logic.

AVOID LIKE THE PLAGUE

People are expecting a DLC 1/4 the price of its base game to be way more than it was ever promised to be. This DLC does nothing to radically change Darkest Dungeon, but it gives you an excuse to replay a fantastic game with a few new twists. There is a new area where you fight waves of enemies instead of treading through dungeons, and fighting in this area gives you the materials to make new powerful trinkets, with a lot more control over what you get compared to the nomad wagon or dungeon loot. It also adds a new boss that can appear randomly in certain areas, but you know which area he is in at any given time, so you can avoid him or seek him out as you wish. It doesn't add a ton of content, but it adds enough for its price point imo, and what it adds is at least on par with everything else in the game. If you like darkest dungeon, you'll like this DLC. Just don't expect it to revolutionize the game or anything.

I have yet to be disappointed by a DD DLC, and they're so well costed, too. For this specifically, I can definitely say there's enough content here to make it worth the money ($6 for my region). The new trinkets are especially neat.

A lot of the negative reviews seem to be for a distaste for the endless battle mode in the new region. But it's exactly as advertised, so, maybe take it into account before purchase. I can see how it wouldn't appeal to everyone. It's definitely tough but I don't think that there's a shortage of viable strategies, either.
